Award.AwardTitle: Interface Control for Systems of Strongly Coupled Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interactive systems are ubiquitous in technological applications and critical for modern society. An important class of such coupled systems have components with differing dynamic properties, whose coupling occurs at the interface of the different media in which each component evolves. The role of a control action is to force the system to behave in a desired, pre-assigned way: suppressing flutter, suppressing turbulence, hitting a target, etc. One eloquent illustration is flutter in aero-elasticity, a phenomenon that may occur when a structure is subject to a surrounding gas or fluid flow. It results in a periodic-like instability that can be fatal for structural stability due to fatigue of the material, such as the collapse of the Tacoma Narrows Bridge in 1940 during strong winds. In such flow-structure interactions, the control action of flutter suppression can be used to avoid structural failure. Another illustration of control is the suppression of turbulence arising in a fluid as part of fluid-structure interaction. Examples include body fluids flowing within arterial walls or veins and motion of a solid vehicle immersed in a fluid, be it an aircraft flying in the air, a ship or a submarine moving in water, etc. Another area of interest is non-linear acoustics, in particular high intensity ultrasound, which has innumerable uses in medical and industrial technology: lithotripsy, thermotherapy, ultrasonic cleansing, detection of cracks, concealed weapon detection, etc. This project aims to extend and deepen the mathematical underpinnings of control systems for these and other important applications.

The research project is focused on the study of control-theoretic issues for systems of strongly coupled partial differential equations (PDE), where the (active, passive) control action is exercised in the transmission conditions at the interface between two media. One example is a hyperbolic-like/hyperbolic interaction: a von Karman plate (displacement of an aircraft wing) sitting in the horizontal plane is immersed in, and interacts with, a 3D-gas flow which occupies the upper-half space and moves over the plate. The flow is mathematically modeled by a modified wave equation in terms of the flow potential, allowing various types of boundary conditions. Couplings occurs in each equation through the trace of the other variable. The normalized constant speed of the passing flow determines regimes: subsonic, transonic and supersonic. Mathematical studies of this system include: (i) well-posedness of various models under various types of boundary conditions; (ii) stability and attractors for the structure, to include control techniques for flutter suppression at both subsonic and supersonic regimes. Another example is the parabolic-hyperbolic interaction, which couples a fluid-gas equation inside the vessel with the full vectorial Karman (shell) dynamical equation, describing the external shell. Here again, mathematical studies of the system include (i) well-posedness and (ii) stabilization by means of stabilizing controls acting on the plate to transmit dissipation on the unstable fluid. In many acoustic applications, only the external boundary is accessible, not the interior. Control theoretic methods can also be applied to the acoustic equation, a third order (in time) PDE with either Dirichlet or Neumann boundary controls. Specific topics of study include: (i) optimal regularity from the boundary to the interior and its trace (ii) exact boundary controllability, (iii) boundary stabilization; (iv) optimal control and min-max game theory with quadratic cost functional. The research involves a diverse set of tools including non-linear functional analysis, micro-local analysis, and Riemannian geometry methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview of systems under study. The present proposal investigated control-theoretic properties of systems described by strongly coupled partial differential equations. A qualitative description thereof is as follows. Many phenomena in the physical sciences, as well as in the biological and economical sciences, are modeled by systems of coupled dynamical equations such as partial differential equations, evolving in time. The dynamical components may be defined on the same physical domain with coupling exercised throughout all of it; or on contiguous physical domains with coupling exercised at the interface between them. Moreover, the evolutionary character of the dynamical components may be the same; or radically different, say a diffusive component coupled with an oscillatory component. The distinctive feature of control theory rests in devising appropriate input/control functions, minimally invasive, as to steer the system under control to achieve a pre-assigned desirable goal. For instance, from instability to stability. Thus, active intervention, not passive contemplation. Physically relevant illustrative systems that were studied include the following ones: fluid-structure interactions; flow-structure interactions; thermo-elastic systems; structural acoustic chambers etc. In the first case, the structure may be static within the fluid (case of small rapid oscillations) or may be moving within the fluid. Single components were also studied such as Navier-Stokes equations for fluids and third order (in time) equations arising in non-linear acoustics; in particular, in High-Intensity Ultrasound.

Summary of outcomes. This research has solved some long-standing open problems. One is flutter suppression in the subsonic case and some supersonic cases in flow-structure interaction. Previous studies were mostly experimental/computational, not theoretical. Another is turbulence suppression (stabilization) in fluid-structure interaction as well as for individual canonical components such as the Navier-Stokes equations for fluids and the Boussinesq system that couples the Navier-Stokes equations with a thermal equation. More specifically, uniform stabilization of Navier-Stokes of physical dimension D=3 was established, by means of localized, boundary-based feedback controllers that moreover are finite dimensional. Establishing finite dimensionality in dimension 3 was the feature that had escaped past investigations, since this problem was introduced in the early 2000. Its solution required a radically different functional setting with respect to the literature of the past 20 years. In addition, this research has opened-up another chapter of investigation on new partial differential equations, third order in time, arising in non-linear equations. Several problems of well-posedness and stabilization, also from the boundary, were resolved. This research has generated many papers published in top journals by the authors, their collaborators, their PhD students and their Post Docs. They are listed in the appropriate form.

Intellectual merits. The present study has infused a broad array of modern, technical mathematical techniques and approaches to investigate and solve numerous critical control-theoretical problems for a representative set of systems of strongly coupled partial differential equations. In all cases, the coupling between them is typically strong; meaning that the behavior of the entire coupled unit is not the sum of the behavior of each single component. For instance, a mismatch of dynamical properties may be present at the interface between components of quite different character.

Broader Impacts. (1) Regarding the potential of the study undertaken within the NSF mission (Act of 1950), it suffices to single out the study under this grant in aeroelasticity concerning which we quote from the authoritative Nasa Mission Statement: ?Flutter is self-sustaining, rapid vibration that occurs when aerodynamics forces (for instance lift) couple with structural vibrational modes. If the feedback between the aerodynamic load and the structure is not naturally damped, the excitations in the structure can grow to a destructive level. Flutters occurs in a variety of instances: aircraft wings, bridges, and buildings in response to strong winds. A big part of what needs to be studied is how to predict flutter, how to reduce it and how to suppress it? The historical disaster of the Tacoma bridge (due to strong winds) is a painful reminder of consequences if flutter suppression is not achieved. (2) Mentoring and training numerous PhD students and Post docs in the Department of Mathematical Sciences, University of Memphis, including several (no less than 6) female students. (3) Three of the PI?s PhD students have been awarded highly competitive NSF summer Internships: two at the Argonne National Laboratory (summer 2019); one at the UCLA Dept of Mathematics (summer 2020, remote) and one at the Oak Ridge National Lab (summer 2020, remote); and one again at the Oak Ridge National Lab (summer 2021, remote). The Pis, along with their collaborators, have presented their results at numerous National and International Conferences: AMS, SIAM, IFIP, etc. Moreover, the PIs have organized special sessions at such conferences. During Spring 2021, I.L. was an Eisenberg Professor and R.T. was a Research Professor at the Semester on the Mathematical Theory of Fluid, held at the University of California, Berkeley.
